required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Breath Synchronized Abdominal Muscle Stimulation to Facilitate Ventilator Weaning: a Pilot Study
clinical_study.official_title: Breath Synchronized Abdominal Muscle Stimulation to Facilitate Ventilator Weaning: a Pilot

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of this study is to determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation applied to the abdominal wall muscles in synchrony with exhalation can increase the strength of the respiratory muscles in prolonged mechanical ventilation patients.

detailed_description.textblock:
In the U.S. over 500,000 patients have difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation every year. These patients cost the health care system $16 billion annually and have an increased risk of medical complications and morbidity.
A major factor responsible for weaning failure is the imbalance between decreased respiratory muscle strength and excessive respiratory load. This study includes an investigational device that applies electrical stimulation to the abdominal muscles in synchrony with exhalation. This is hypothesized to improve the strength of the respiratory muscles. The long term goal of this project is to determine whether this approach can reduce the number of days taken for patients to wean from mechanical ventilation.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Maximum Expiratory Pressure From Baseline to Extubation
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to first extubation, an expected average of 4 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Maximum expiratory pressure was measured from total lung capacity

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Maximum Inspiratory Pressure From Baseline to Extubation
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to first extubation, an expected average of 4 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Maximum inspiratory pressure was measured from end expiratory lung volume.

secondary_outcome.description: Thickness of transverse abdominis muscle as measured by ultrasound

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to first extubation, an expected average of 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Thickness of the external oblique muscle as measured by ultrasound

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to first extubation, an expected average of 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Thickness of the internal oblique muscle as measured by ultrasound

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to first extubation, an expected average of 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Thickness of the rectus abdominis muscle as measured by ultrasound

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to first extubation, an expected average of 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Thickness of the diaphragm as measured by ultrasound

secondary_outcome.time_frame: The earlier of 6 weeks or first extubation, an expected average of 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Defined as free from ventilator support for more than 72 hours

secondary_outcome.time_frame: The earlier of 6 weeks or first extubation, an expected average of 4 weeks

secondary_outcome.description: Cough peak flow was measured from total lung capacity

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to final study visit or first extubation, an expected average of 4 weeks

secondary_outcome.description: Measured using the behavioral pain scale

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Adverse Events That Are Related to Treatment
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Though study completion, an expected average of 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: This includes any adverse event that was graded as having a possible, probable or definite relationship to the study intervention.

intervention.description: VentFree prototype (VF03) that delivers electrical stimulation pulses to the abdominal muscles during exhalation with a frequency of 30 Hz, a pulse width of 350 µs and 90% of the maximum current that the participant can tolerate. These stimulation parameters were selected to cause a tetanic (continuous) contraction of the abdominal muscles, without pain for the patient. Stimulation will be administered for 30 minutes 2 times per day, 5 days per week, for 6 weeks; or until the patient is weaned from mechanical ventilation.

Modified VentFree prototype (VF03) that delivers stimulation pulses to the abdominal muscles during exhalation with a frequency of 10 Hz, a pulse width of 100 µs and current set to 10 milliamp. These stimulation parameters were chosen to cause a twitch contraction of the abdominal wall muscles. Stimulation will be administered for 30 minutes, 2 times per day, 5 days per week, for 6 weeks; or until the patient is weaned from mechanical ventilation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients who have been mechanically ventilated for at least fourteen days.
- Clinically stable: oxygen saturation > 90% with a fractional inspired oxygen ≤ 0.40, external positive end expiratory pressure ≤ 5 centimeters water, temperature ranging from 35.5 to 38.5 degrees celsius, no intravenous administration of vasoactive agents.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients in whom Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) does not elicit a palpable contraction of the abdominal muscles.
- Patients with broken or irritated skin on the abdominal wall
- Patients with a history of neuromuscular disease
- Body Mass Index (BMI) > 35 kg/m2
- Patients who are not medically stable
- Patients with a pacemaker
- Female patients who are pregnant
- Patients under the age of 18
- Patients who are expected to die within four weeks
- Patients who are unable to follow verbal instructions
- Patients with epilepsy
- Patients with an abdominal wall hernia
- Patients with anoxic encephalopathy
- Patients with history of, or active, substance abuse

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: VentFree Stimulation
group.description: Breath synchronized abdominal NMES Breath synchronized abdominal NMES: VentFree prototype (VF03) that delivers electrical stimulation pulses to the abdominal muscles during exhalation with a frequency of 30 Hz, a pulse width of 350 µs and 90% of the maximum current that the participant can tolerate. These stimulation parameters were selected to cause a tetanic (continuous) contraction of the abdominal muscles, without pain for the patient. Stimulation will be administered for 30 minutes 2 times per day, 5 days per week, for 6 weeks; or until the patient is weaned from mechanical ventilation.

group.title: Sham Stimulation
group.description: Sham breath synchronized abdominal NMES Sham breath synchronized abdominal NMES: Modified VentFree prototype (VF03) that delivers stimulation pulses to the abdominal muscles during exhalation with a frequency of 10 Hz, a pulse width of 100 µs and current set to 10 milliamp. These stimulation parameters were chosen to cause a twitch contraction of the abdominal wall muscles. Stimulation will be administered for 30 minutes, 2 times per day, 5 days per week, for 6 weeks; or until the patient is weaned from mechanical ventilation.

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Duration of mechanical ventilation at enrollment
Primary reason for mechanical ventilation
Cause of acute respiratory failure
Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II (APACHE II) score
measure.description: The APACHE II score is a widely used ICU prognostic scale that is a measurement of patient disease severity and strongly correlates with patient outcomes. The APACHE II is an integer score from 0 to 71; higher scores correspond to more severe disease and a higher risk of death.

reported_events.desc: Adverse events were reviewed during every study intervention session

group.title: VentFree Stimulation
group.description: Breath synchronized abdominal NMES Breath synchronized abdominal NMES: VentFree prototype (VF03) that delivers electrical stimulation pulses to the abdominal muscles during exhalation with a frequency of 30 Hz, a pulse width of 350 µs and 90% of the maximum current that the participant can tolerate. These stimulation parameters were selected to cause a tetanic (continuous) contraction of the abdominal muscles, without pain for the patient. Stimulation will be administered for 30 minutes 2 times per day, 5 days per week, for 6 weeks; or until the patient is weaned from mechanical ventilation.

group.title: Sham Stimulation
group.description: Sham breath synchronized abdominal NMES Sham breath synchronized abdominal NMES: Modified VentFree prototype (VF03) that delivers stimulation pulses to the abdominal muscles during exhalation with a frequency of 10 Hz, a pulse width of 100 µs and current set to 10 milliamp. These stimulation parameters were chosen to cause a twitch contraction of the abdominal wall muscles. Stimulation will be administered for 30 minutes, 2 times per day, 5 days per week, for 6 weeks; or until the patient is weaned from mechanical ventilation.

event.description: Mean arterial pressure was elevated to 128 mmHg prior to initiation of treatment. Adverse event was assessed with Moderate severity, no relationship with study device, and was resolved with no sequel.
Adverse event was rated with Mild severity and Definitely related to study intervention. Resolved with no sequel
Adverse event was assessed with Moderate severity and unrelated to study intervention. Resolved with no sequel.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
